newsitem.title: SWEDEN: FOCUS-Nordbanken sees end to credit losses.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS-Nordbanken sees end to credit losses.

text.p: Commercial bank Nordbanken, one of three Swedish financial institutions reporting half-yearly results on Wednesday, posted 18 percent profit growth and an end to the credit losses that have plagued it for years.

The state-controlled retail bank showed an operating profit of 3.8 billion crowns ($576 million) for the first half of the year, a healthy improvement on the 3.21 billion crowns recorded in the same 1995 period.
Credit losses fell to 260 million crowns from 661 million last year. Much of this improvement was due to the exploitation of a loan loss provision totalling 300 million crowns.

However, even without this provision, credit losses would have totalled no more than 0.49 percent of total lending, a level which signals that Nordbanken -- along with other Swedish banks -- has normalised loan loss levels at around 0.5 percent.
Even so, the improvement in earnings was by no means only the result of lower credit losses. A steady decline in market interest rates over the period had boosted profitability, Nordbanken said.

Debt yields in Sweden have fallen hardest at the short end of the market, while the rise in yields over the long term -- a steepening yield curve -- has allowed banks to cover long lending with cheaper borrowing in short-dated paper.
Lower rates also led to strong gains in the bank's bond portfolio, Nordbanken said in a statement.

"The general downturn in rates influenced developments positively mainly through higher bond prices. Advantageous positioning (in the market) led to a strong improvement in the result from financial transactions," it said.
This item improved to 632 million crowns from just 45 million crowns in the first half of last year.

The bank also noted improvements on the cost side. Although personnel costs increased to 1.43 billion crowns from 1.38 billion last year, a fall in other operating costs meant a six percent decline in total expenses to 3.58 billion crowns.
Since the credit crash of the early 1990s which brought many Swedish banks cap-in-hand to the finance ministry for help, the industry has recovered with a vengeance.
Nordbanken's huge portfolio of bad debt and non-performing loans was hived off in a government rescue package, and the bank's highly profitable core operations have now come back into their own.

Nordbanken's profit after tax of 2.68 billion crowns for the first half means a return on equity of a solid 28 percent, and even discounting the result of financial transactions the return was 21 percent.
Smaller rival Foreningsbanken -- Sweden's traditional farmers' bank -- told a similar story, posting a 24 percent rise in operating profits for the first half to 524 million crowns.

Without the benefit of state subsidies, Foreningsbanken has had to bear a proportionally higher burden of loan losses than Nordbanken, although this item has now declined to a manageable 500 million crowns from 723 million last year.
More worrying was a decline in total income to 2.46 billion crowns from 2.53 billion last year, something the bank ascribed to a squeeze on margins from lower interest rates.

Mortgage institute Stadshypotek, in which the state has a 34 percent holding, reported a nine percent improvement in profit after credit losses to 1.55 billion crowns, with loan losses falling to 335 million crowns from 592 million.
Although Stadshypotek specialises in housing loans, the group's newly-started banking arm reported an increase in customer deposits to 3.3 billion crowns from 600 million.
